Line 3: Line 3:  
'''Love''' has several different meanings in [[English language|English]], from something that gives a little pleasure ("I loved that meal") to something one would die for ([[patriotism]], pairbonding). It can describe an intense feeling of [[affection]], an [[emotion]] or an emotional state. In ordinary use, it usually refers to interpersonal love. Probably due to its psychological relevance, love is one of the most common themes in art.
 
'''Love''' has several different meanings in [[English language|English]], from something that gives a little pleasure ("I loved that meal") to something one would die for ([[patriotism]], pairbonding). It can describe an intense feeling of [[affection]], an [[emotion]] or an emotional state. In ordinary use, it usually refers to interpersonal love. Probably due to its psychological relevance, love is one of the most common themes in art.
    −
Love might best defined as acting intentionally, in response to others (including God), to promote overall well-being (Oord). In this, love has a degree of freedom and this freedom is expressed in relation to others in the effort to promote the common good.
+
Love might best be defined as the decision to make an unconditional commitment to giving yourself to an other. To love a person is to unconditionally give yourself to that person, despite any suffering they may cause you. For the best example of this kind of love, see Shel Silverstein's [[The Giving Tree]]. Any cultural distinction given to the word "love," as enumerated below in this article, falls under this definition. This definition of love is also known to have been watered down into "types" or "categories" because of a perpetual confusion of love with emotion, affection, sexual urges, and, in particular, all and any manifestation of desire. It may also be due to the immensely painful state of vulnerability and responsibility involved with this decision, forcing many to fabricate an easier, less painful definition. (see [[Rilke]]) But essentially, it is a choice, whose truest and purest form emanates from its basis upon what is referred to as intuition, instinct, gut-feeling, the heart, or the voice of God. In this way, it is truly selfess, timeless, and unbreakable because the choice is borne out of something beyond one's temporal and transient self.
−   −
Love can also essentially be defined as the decision to make an unconditional commitment to giving yourself to an other. For the best example of this kind of love, see Shel Silverstein's [[The Giving Tree]]. All the distinctions that many different world cultures have given to the word "love" fall under this definition, as enumerated three paragraphs below. This definition of love is also known to have been watered down into "types" or "categories" because of a perpetual confusion of love with emotion, affection, sexual urges, and, in particular, desire. It may also be due to the immensely painful state of vulnerability and responsibility involved with this decision. (see [[Rilke]]) But essentially, it is a choice, whose truest and purest form emanates from its basis upon what is referred to as intuition, instinct, gut-feeling, or the voice of God.
       
Love is inherent in all human cultures. It is precisely these cultural differences that make any universal definition of love difficult, but not impossible, to establish. See the [[Sapir-Whorf hypothesis]].
 
Love is inherent in all human cultures. It is precisely these cultural differences that make any universal definition of love difficult, but not impossible, to establish. See the [[Sapir-Whorf hypothesis]].
